title: Contributor experience: quick build+tests on a Windows machine to test and fix Windows related issues faster
body:
### Feature Spec

As a contributor, I would like to have the option to run my build on a Windows machine solely, for faster feedback loops related to Windows errors.

### Use Cases

Sometimes the build and tests succeed on Linux and Mac, but fail on Windows. A common error is that we forget to normalize path strings.
See [this example](https://github.com/winglang/wing/actions/runs/5077675549/jobs/9121654237).
In these cases we usually follow up with a fix PR, but it takes a long time to see if the fix worked, since it has to build again on all environments (Linux, Mac, Node 18/19 etc.).
Instead, we'd like to run the fix PR only on Windows to see if our fix worked.

### Implementation Notes

Perhaps we can add a label, similar to `pr/e2e-full`, named `pr/e2e-windows`. When this label is added to a PR, the build would only run on Windows. 
After the build succeeds, we need a way to re-run our fix in the normal path, so it will get tested, merged to main and later published like every other PR.

### Component

Contributor Experience

### Community Notes

<!-- Please keep this note for the community -->
* Please vote by adding a üëç reaction to the issue to help us prioritize.
* If you are interested to work on this issue, please leave a comment.

title: Build sporadically fails in CI when installing npm using volta
body: Sometimes our builds on the main branch or on contributor branches fail with an error saying that it was unable to install node (see screenshot below). It happens maybe once a week on average. The current workaround is to retry the workflow. suggestions from @MarkMcCulloh: > Volta‚Äôs install process goes directly to [nodejs.org](http://nodejs.org/) every time which seems to be flakey. Wish it cached‚Ä¶ We could either set up caching ourselves or just skip using volta. The upside of using volta is that it matches the documented dev recommendation and removes duplication of specifying node/npm version. Not sure it‚Äôs worth it anymore, so I‚Äôm cool with just removing volta from CI.

title: Skip publishing new version of VS code extension when

labels.name: üîå vscode-extension
labels.description: Issues related to the Wing VS Code extension

body:
### Feature Spec

Currently, we publish a new version of the VS Code extension every time we publish a new version of the wignlang toolchain. However, the extension does not actually take a tight dependency on the toolchain version - it defaults to using whichever version you have installed on your system's PATH.

If a new commit is pushed to our repo's main branch without any changes in the `apps/vscode` directory, then the extension's code will not change, so there isn't really a need to publish a new version of the extension.

### Use Cases

Reduce the number of times users have to update their VS Code extension.

### Implementation Notes

I think the most straightforward option (to avoid maintaining a separate line of versions) is to simply skip publishing some versions of the extension, allowing gaps in the version numbering of the VS Code extension. I've seen this done in some other domains (e.g. AWS SDK for JS is broken into several hundred npm libraries, but not all of them are updated every time)

### Component

IDE Extension

### Community Notes

<!-- Please keep this note for the community -->
* Please vote by adding a üëç reaction to the issue to help us prioritize.
* If you are interested to work on this issue, please leave a comment.

title: `size` primitive type
body:
### Community Note

> Please vote by adding a üëç reaction to the issue to help us prioritize.
> If you are interested to work on this issue, please leave a comment.


### Feature Spec

Similar to the `duration` type in the language, but for representing sizes of data and converting between different representations.

Literal syntax TBD

```js
let x: size = ???; // 40 KB
log(x.bytes); // 40,000
log(x.kilobytes); // 40
```

### Use Cases

Converting between and representing sizes of file or data. 

### Implementation Notes

Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cdk/api/v2/docs/aws-cdk-lib.Size.html

### Component

Language Design, SDK

title: Naming a resource method with the same name as a field causes a compiler panic
Update Counter.inc, peek, and dec with `key` argument
string interpolation fails on dollar sign
body:
### Community Note

<!-- Please keep this note for the community -->
> Please vote by adding a üëç reaction to the issue to help us prioritize.
> If you are interested to work on this issue, please leave a comment.


### I tried this:

```ts (wing)
print("this cost $50");
```

### I expected this:

To compile and work

### Instead, this happened:

It assumed that I am doing string interpolation because of the `$` sign 
```sh
Compilation failed with 1 errors
Error at code.w:1:18 | Unknown parser error.
```

### Component:

Compiler

### Wing Version:

0.4.61

### Node.js Version:

_No response_

### Platform(s):

_No response_

### Anything else?

_No response_
